docs.lead_paragraph: Egypt's revenue from tourism has dropped 40 percent since the riots last week by police conscripts, the Minister of Tourism said today. The minister, Fouad Abdel Latif Sultan, said, ''If the present drop continues at the current rate, it could be a kind of crisis for tourism in Egypt.'' Mr. Sultan said only 8,000 tourists had arrived since February 26, compared with 18,000 in the corresponding period last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO shocks have sent Mexico reeling in the last year - a devastating earthquake that rocked Mexico City and this winter's collapse of world oil prices. The country has generally recovered from the first shock, burying its dead and rebuilding. But the oil trauma will cause more lasting economic devastation, and Mexico has begun a desperate search for ways to replace its largest source of foreign earnings. Suddenly, tourism - an industry whose fortunes sagged dramatically for the past few years - is a major Government priority. President Miguel de la Madrid has declared it as such, and the Government has started an ambitious new campaign to revitalize the industry. It is seeking to attract more tourists by such moves as easing rules on air charter tour operators and increasing services and protection for tourists on Mexico's highways and in its courts. Tourism officials are trying to attract foreign investors to build new hotels and resorts. Japanese investors, for example, are backing a $130 million luxury hotel that is rising on Mexico City's skyline.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House today overwhelmingly approved the creation of a Travel and Tourism Administration to encourage foreigners to travel in the United States. Representative James D. Santini, Democrat of Nevada, said the American share of spending by foreign tourists, which is more than $100 billion a year, had dropped to 10 percent from 13 percent because there was ''no coordinated endeavor to recognize the importance of foreign tourism.''
